Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hello Ron, and thanks for the interesting reply. I have posted a few times =
before in this forum which I think have answered your question about my exp=
eriences.=A0 They would be under Rick or Rj.=A0 To summarize, I have not po=
sted any clips, and I do not have any results that I would make any claims =
about at all.=A0 My interests here are more in the areas of process and met=
hodologies.

I have gathered, as you noted, that may of the members here ar=
en't really doing anything scientific, but are more in the hobbyist or enth=
usiast mode.=A0 That's cool.=A0 I know of people who like to go fishing, ju=
st to enjoy the company, or the alone-time, and don;t want to catch anythin=
g or produce anything either, but just enjoy the time.=A0 I'm certainly not=
 trying to tell people what to do with their time!

But just in cast there =
is someone reading, who might like to use some methodology to help them tes=
t and refine their ideas, or who is not just one of the hobbyists to which =
you allude, but trying to be a researcher who can show objective results, o=
r hopes to make progress with their innovation, I present these ideas.=A0 T=
hey are, actually, not what one would call a full blown scientific methodol=
ogy (since in this case, that would require first proving that there are sp=
irits out there before trying to claim that they are what are shaping the n=
oises on your device).=A0 But they are a tool to help direct anyone who is =
trying different techniques, and looking for an objective way to determine =
which techniques seem to be the most promising.=A0 I don't think this is lo=
oking for proof of anything, or trying to debunk anything.=A0 It's just try=
ing to assess experimental results, which in this field I understood can be=
 tricky.=A0 As Misty noted, different people can
 hear different things tha=
n she does, and its a nice surprise when they do hear the same thing.=A0 Ma=
ybe it would be an even nicer surprise if, under the conditions I outlined,=
 a lot of people heard the same things!

Again, I am not trying to advocate=
 debunking your creativity or ideas. But for anyone who is looking for some=
 new tools, this time in the realm of process and methodology, to help them=
 with their explorations, I'd be happy to offer more ideas there.=A0 Were t=
here any points in my process Ron that you took exception to, don't find va=
lue in, or think can be improved?,

            Hello RJ=A0 You make good p=
oints here.=A0 I had to re look at the purpose of the group to see if this =
was a scientific research group or other.=A0 It looks like it is in the "or=
 other" category.=A0 I do believe there are strictly research groups around=
 that can apply the rules of scientific testing.=A0 More in the hobbyist or=
 enthusiast mode?
=A0
One=A0 of the reasons I joined this group=A0is becaus=
e I appreciate members like Misty for posting their=A0work and not having t=
o do so under some=A0scientific methodology.=A0=A0That, I think, would hind=
er innovation, testing, sharing and even enjoyment of what we do here.=A0 A=
nd, again, it is not the stated purpose of this group.=A0=A0Doubters and de=
bunkers certainly have a place in this non-scientific arena, but here I hop=
e to see posts from people who are not afraid to=A0try a technique and then=
 share it with others.=A0=A0I was looking for your posts=A0with the group h=
ere...do you have any?=A0 I do not mean that as a challenge... I am sincere=
ly interested in hearing=A0your clips.=A0=A0=A0best wishes=A0=A0 ron l=A0=
=A0

--- On Wed, 1/14/09, Rj <rastere=
r@yahoo. com> wrote:


From: Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com>
Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC=
] New Water EVP
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
Date: Wednesday, January 14, 2=
009, 8:15 AM








I know what you mean Misty - it does seem that interpr=
etations are often varied.=A0 I am thinking that the best way to make progr=
ess is to get an audio sample that you think is most representative of a gi=
ven approach's effectiveness, and send that privately to several people.=A0=
 Name the file something innocuous (like File1) and don';t tell the people =
you send it to what you think you hear.=A0 Also, ask the people not to disc=
uss the file with anyone else, and have them send what they think they hear=
 directly back to you,rather than posting the results in a forum or group.
=

I think that kind of test is helpful, since it seems to me that once someo=
ne tells me what the audio clip sounds like, then it's hard for me to hear =
anything else in it.=A0 But,that could be influencing my interpretation (li=
ke someone pointing to a cloud, telling me its a horse, and then I have tro=
uble NOT seeing a horse) ,so it's better to listen
 before it is suggested =
to me what i should be hearing.

This way, I think the most progress can be=
 made, because if people just keep confirming what we think we hear, and it=
 turns out it's just noise that we are forcing an interpretation into, we w=
on't be making progress (though it might make us feel good to believe that =
we're being successful).=A0 Getting negative feedback to one's approach is =
not as fun, and might feel like some non-believer is trying to debunk us.=
=A0 But, really, that can be the best feedback for progress, since it helps=
 us to change tactics when our current approach is not effective, rather th=
an continuing down an ineffective path, getting accolades from friends, but=
 missing out on other paths that might show more promise,.

I never k=
now who will hear what. No matter which method is used. Everyone hears diff=
erently, different speaker setups, different software. I just post a variet=
y of whats clear to me using different methods. Sometimes the one thats not=
 one I think of as clear is the one everyone agrees on as being clear. Go f=
igure.

Misty

Content-Type: text/html; charset=us-ascii

<table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0" ><tr><td valign="top" style="font: inherit;">Hello Ron, and thanks for the interesting reply. I have posted a few times before in this forum which I think have answered your question about my experiences.  They would be under Rick or Rj.  To summarize, I have not posted any clips, and I do not have any results that I would make any claims about at all.  My interests here are more in the areas of process and methodologies.<br><br>I have gathered, as you noted, that may of the members here aren't really doing anything scientific, but are more in the hobbyist or enthusiast mode.  That's cool.  I know of people who like to go fishing, just to enjoy the company, or the alone-time, and don;t want to catch anything or produce anything either, but just enjoy the time.  I'm certainly not trying to tell people what to do with their time!<br><br>But just in cast there is someone
 reading, who might like to use some methodology to help them test and refine their ideas, or who is not just one of the hobbyists to which you allude, but trying to be a researcher who can show objective results, or hopes to make progress with their innovation, I present these ideas.  They are, actually, not what one would call a full blown scientific methodology (since in this case, that would require first proving that there are spirits out there before trying to claim that they are what are shaping the noises on your device).  But they are a tool to help direct anyone who is trying different techniques, and looking for an objective way to determine which techniques seem to be the most promising.  I don't think this is looking for proof of anything, or trying to debunk anything.  It's just trying to assess experimental results, which in this field I understood can be tricky.  As Misty noted, different people can hear different
 things than she does, and its a nice surprise when they do hear the same thing.  Maybe it would be an even nicer surprise if, under the conditions I outlined, a lot of people heard the same things!<br><br>Again, I am not trying to advocate debunking your creativity or ideas. But for anyone who is looking for some new tools, this time in the realm of process and methodology, to help them with their explorations, I'd be happy to offer more ideas there.  Were there any points in my process Ron that you took exception to, don't find value in, or think can be improved?, <br><br><br><br>--- On <b>Wed, 1/14/09, Ron Lederer <i><ronriko@...></i></b> wrote:<br><blockquote style="border-left: 2px solid rgb(16, 16, 255); margin-left: 5px; padding-left: 5px;"><br>From: Ron Lederer <ronriko@...><br>Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] New Water EVP<br>To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com<br>Date: Wednesday, January 14, 2009, 9:04 AM<br><br><div
 id="yiv1915050441">





    <div id="ygrp-text">
            <p><table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tbody><tr><td style="font-family: inherit; font-style: inherit; font-variant: inherit; font-weight: inherit; font-size: inherit; line-height: inherit; font-size-adjust: inherit; font-stretch: inherit; -x-system-font: none;" valign="top"><div>Hello RJ  You make good points here.  I had to re look at the purpose of the group to see if this was a scientific research group or other.  It looks like it is in the "or other" category.  I do believe there are strictly research groups around that can apply the rules of scientific testing.  More in the hobbyist or enthusiast mode?</div>
<div> </div>
<div>One  of the reasons I joined this group is because I appreciate members like Misty for posting their work and not having to do so under some scientific methodology.  That, I think, would hinder innovation, testing, sharing and even enjoyment of what we do here.  And, again, it is not the stated purpose of this group.  Doubters and debunkers certainly have a place in this non-scientific arena, but here I hope to see posts from people who are not afraid to try a technique and then share it with others.  I was looking for your posts with the group here...do you have any?  I do not mean that as a challenge... I am sincerely interested in hearing your clips.   best wishes   ron l  <br></div>
<div><font size="3" face="comic sans ms"><em></em></font> </div>
<div><font size="3" face="comic sans ms"><em></em></font> </div>
<div><font size="3" face="comic sans ms"><em></em></font> </div>
<div><font size="3" face="comic sans ms"><em></em></font> </div>
<div><font size="3" face="comic sans ms"><em>                                                  Reality Is Your Idea</em></font></div><br><br>--- On <b>Wed, 1/14/09, <span>Rj</span> <i><rasterer@yahoo. com></i></b> wrote:<br>
<blockquote style="border-left: 2px solid rgb(16, 16, 255);"><br>From: Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com><br>Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] New Water EVP<br>To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com<br>Date: Wednesday, January 14, 2009, 8:15 AM<br><br>
<div id="yiv1521001901">
<div id="ygrp-text">
<div>
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td valign="top">I know what you mean Misty - it does seem that interpretations are often varied.  I am thinking that the best way to make progress is to get an audio sample that you think is most representative of a given approach's effectiveness, and send that privately to several people.  Name the file something innocuous (like File1) and don';t tell the people you send it to what you think you hear.  Also, ask the people not to discuss the file with anyone else, and have them send what they think they hear directly back to you,rather than posting the results in a forum or group.<br><br>I think that kind of test is helpful, since it seems to me that once someone tells me what the audio clip sounds like, then it's hard for me to hear anything else in it.  But,that could be influencing my interpretation (like someone pointing to a cloud, telling me its a horse, and then I have trouble NOT seeing a horse) ,so it's better to listen
 before it is suggested to me what i should be hearing.<br><br>This way, I think the most progress can be made, because if people just keep confirming what we think we hear, and it turns out it's just noise that we are forcing an interpretation into, we won't be making progress (though it might make us feel good to believe that we're being successful).  Getting negative feedback to one's approach is not as fun, and might feel like some non-believer is trying to debunk us.  But, really, that can be the best feedback for progress, since it helps us to change tactics when our current approach is not effective, rather than continuing down an ineffective path, getting accolades from friends, but missing out on other paths that might show more promise,.<br><br><br>--- On <b>Tue, 1/13/09, Misty Dawn <i><bulletbabea@ yahoo.com></i></b> wrote:<br>
<blockquote style="border-left: 2px solid rgb(16, 16, 255);"><br>From: Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com><br>Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] New Water EVP<br>To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com<br>Date: Tuesday, January 13, 2009, 7:37 PM<br><br>
<div id="yiv1524022871">
<div id="ygrp-text">
<div>Thanks RJ<br><br>I never know who will hear what. No matter which method is used. Everyone hears differently, different speaker setups, different software. I just post a variety of whats clear to me using different methods. Sometimes the one thats not one I think of as clear is the one everyone agrees on as being clear. Go figure.<br><br>Misty<br><br>--- On Tue, 1/13/09, Rj <<a rel="nofollow">rasterer@yahoo. com</a>> wrote:<br><br>> From: Rj <<a rel="nofollow">rasterer@yahoo. com</a>><br>> Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] New Water EVP<br>> To: <a rel="nofollow">EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com</a><br>> Date: Tuesday, January 13, 2009, 3:56 PM<br>> If you'd like some feedback, I could definitely make out<br>> what sounded like water, and perhaps slowed down water. <br>> But other than that, it seemed a strain to me to attribute<br>> any of those noises to anything vocal or intelligent.<br>> <br>> Just my opinion,<br>>
 <br>> --- On Tue, 1/13/09, Misty Dawn<br>> <<a rel="nofollow">bulletbabea@ yahoo.com</a>> wrote:<br>> <br>> From: Misty Dawn <<a rel="nofollow">bulletbabea@ yahoo.com</a>><br>> Subject: [EVP-ITC] New Water EVP<br>> To: <a rel="nofollow">EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com</a><br>> Date: Tuesday, January 13, 2009, 10:31 AM<br>> <br>> <br>> <br>> <br>> <br>> <br>> <br>> <br>> <br>> <br>> <br>> Heres a few voices from my latest session<br>> recording water then slowing down -74% in audacity. For me<br>> they are quite loud and the clarity was great. I recorded<br>> these on a night of the full moon (which does seem to help).<br>> <br>> <br>> <br>> Attaching a few of the clearer ones to this post and for<br>> those who dont get the dailies you can listen on my esnips<br>> site. For the other methods click on my profile there and<br>> you will see folders listed.<br>>
 <br>> <br>> <br>> <a rel="nofollow" target="_blank" href="http://www.esnips./">http://www.esnips.</a> com/web/NewEVPVo ices<br>> <br>> <br>> <br>> Misty<br><br></div></div></div></blockquote></td></tr></tbody></table><br></div></div></div></blockquote></td></tr></tbody></table><br>

      </p>
    </div>
